Package com.ibm.streams.operator.samples.sinks

Class HttpPOST

java.lang.Object
com.ibm.streams.operator.AbstractOperator
com.ibm.streams.operator.samples.patterns.TupleConsumer
com.ibm.streams.operator.samples.sinks.HttpPOST
All Implemented Interfaces:
Operator
@PrimitiveOperator(name="HTTPPost", description="Sink operator where incoming tuples are sent as an HTTP POST requests to the URL specified in the operator specific `url` parameter.", comment=" Licensed Materials - Property of IBM (C) Copyright Teracloud ApS 2024, 2024, IBM Corp. 2010, 2016 All Rights Reserved. US Government Users Restricted Rights - Use, duplication or disclosure restricted by GSA ADP Schedule Contract with IBM Corp. ") @InputPortSet public class HttpPOST extends TupleConsumer
Sink operator where incoming tuples are sent as an HTTP POST requests to the URL specified in the operator specific url parameter.

The POST request contains a query string of all the attribute names with their values obtained using Tuple.getString(). This mimics how an HTML Form with the same attributes and values would be sent.
Multiple tuples may be represented in the POST request, a single tuple per POST request is the default though.

Parameters

  • url - HTTP URL of the server to POST data to.
  • batchSize - Number of tuples to include in each POST request, defaults to 1.

Example SPL invocation
A Java primitive operator model com.ibm.streams.javaprimitivesamples.sinks::HTTPPost is provided in the sample toolkit
$STREAMS_INSTALL/samples/spl/feature/JavaOperators 

  use com.ibm.streams.javaprimitivesamples.sinks::HTTPPost;
  
  ...
  
  () as TestPost = HTTPPost(input-streams)  
   {
     param:
       // Example Jetty - show request info
       url: "http://localhost:8080/dump/info";
       batchSize: 3;
   }

    • processBatch

      protected final boolean processBatch(Queue<TupleConsumer.BatchedTuple> batch) throws Exception
      Process the batch of incoming tuples by creating a POST request from them of the form name=value. Note that multiple values of the same name can be supplied and are supplied when multiple tuples of the same type are present in the batch.

      Since this is an example of extracting data to an external system, exception handling is not covered and exceptions will cause the processing element containing the operator to terminate. If the HTTP Response code is greater or equal to 400 then output from the request error stream will be traced at debug level, otherwise the request output will be traced at debug level.
      A functional HTTP POST operator has to consider a variety of exceptions and how to handle them. The correct approach will depend on the functionality being implemented, options for handling exceptions include:

      • re-trying to submit the tuples, e.g. in an ordering system
      • the incoming tuples being discarded until a valid connection can be made, e.g. for a visual dash board
      • re-trying tuples for a limited time and discarding them after that, e.g. to support temporary connection issues but not submitting data that may be irrelevant due to its age
      • submitting tuples to an optional output port to allow a different processing path for tuples that could not be submitted

      Specified by:
      processBatch in class TupleConsumer
      Parameters:
      batch - Batch of tuples to be processed, its contents are not modified by any incoming tuples.
      Returns:
      True process any tuples left in batch in a future batch, false no tuples are added back for future processing.
      Throws:
      Exception
